rows.title: What is a raw type and why shouldn't we use it?
The Use of Multiple JFrames: Good or Bad Practice? [closed]
Is storing a delimited list in a database column really that bad?
What is a debugger and how can it help me diagnose problems?

66: <p>The biggest problem for me is that including this header file wont compile. So if its there, Ill have to remove it, try to compile, and add the standard header files that are needed.</p>

<p>As explained in the top answer to the <a href="https://www.quora.com/Is-it-good-practice-to-use-include-bits-stdc++-h-in-programming-contests-instead-of-listing-a-lot-of-includes" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Quora question mentioned by @Lightness Races in Orbit</a>, there's nothing wrong with including <code>bits/stdc++.h</code> in the context of a programming competition. The disadvantages around portability, compile time, and standardization are not relevant there. The same would be true in a college programming class if the example code uses that include.</p>
<p>If you're writing production code, then don't use it. It shouldn't be a big deal to switch back and forth depending on the purpose of the code you're currently writing.</p>
68:
<p>In general anything can be defensible if it meets the requirements of your project.  This doesn't mean that people will agree with or want to defend your decision...</p>

<p>In general, storing data in this way is suboptimal (e.g. harder to do efficient queries) and may cause maintenance issues if you modify the items in your form.  Perhaps you could have found a middle ground and used an integer representing a set of bit flags instead?</p>

<p>Yes, it <em>is</em> that bad.  My view is that if you don't like using relational databases then look for an alternative that suits you better, there are lots of interesting "NOSQL" projects out there with some really advanced features.</p>

<p>Well I've been using a key/value pair tab separated list in a NTEXT column in SQL Server for more than 4 years now and it works. You do lose the flexibility of making queries but on the other hand, if you have a library that persists/derpersists the key value pair then it's not a that bad idea.</p>

<p>I would probably take the middle ground: make each field in the CSV into a separate column in the database, but not worry much about normalization (at least for now). At some point, normalization <em>might</em> become interesting, but with all the data shoved into a single column you're gaining virtually no benefit from using a database at all. You need to separate the data into logical fields/columns/whatever you want to call them before you can manipulate it meaningfully at all.</p>

<p>If you have a fixed number of boolean fields, you could use a <code>INT(1) NOT NULL</code> (or <code>BIT NOT NULL</code> if it exists) or <code>CHAR (0)</code> (nullable) for each. You could also use a <code>SET</code> (I forget the exact syntax).</p>
69:
<p>If the frames are going to be the same size, why not create the frame and pass the frame then as a reference to it instead. </p>

<p>When you have passed the frame you can then decide how to populate it. It would be like having a method for calculating the average of a set of figures. Would you create the method over and over again? </p>
<p>It is not a good practice but even though you wish to use it you can use the singleton pattern as its good. I have used the singleton patterns in most of my project its good.</p>
70:
<p>Raw types are fine when they express what you want to express.</p>

<p>For example, a deserialisation function might return a <code>List</code>, but it doesn't know the list's element type. So <code>List</code> is the appropriate return type here.</p>
